div.p: Listening is so important and is different from merely hearing.
Hearing is linked to anatomy and physiology while listening is linked to concentration.
How many times have you heard someone speaking and followed it up with
"what did you say?"Whether it be in conversation with loved ones,
in a meeting on the job, or in the classroom...
listening is a skill that is developed and honed much like any other.
And, like other skills, some find it comes naturally, while others have to make an effort.
How do you improve your listening skills?
First, tune in...pay attention.
Distractions are easy and, sometimes, welcome.
Fight the urge to become distracted.
Stay focused on the speaker.
Be active.
Ask questions.
Listen thoughtfully to the responses.
Review what you have heard immediately and later, after some time has passed.
Another skill required for success in the classroom is note taking during a lecture.
Listening is critical to good note taking.
The listening required here is a little different.
In addition to the content, you'll need to be aware of some other things.
Pay attention to cues.
Did the speaker get louder?
Did she take a few steps forward...maybe stand a bit straighter?
Did she take time to write something on the whiteboard or use the laser pointer?
How often did she repeat the same phrase?
Did she restate the same thing two or three different ways?
And, how much time was spent on a particular topic...just a passing mention
or did significant discussion take place?
These are all things that indicate something important was said.
